awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  Point-of-Care Skin Cancer Imaging Device
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project is to develop an affordable tool to image the skin over its depth while offering large contrasts between normal, malignant, and benign tissues. Such a device will be an invaluable assistance to dermatologists and dermatologic surgeons and significantly enhance the current state of skin cancer detection and management. The proposed system will be integrated in a single framework, resulting in a compact (handheld) and real-time imager at a low manufacturing cost. This will make the proposed technology comparable in cost to dermoscopic imaging, facilitating its widespread use and application. The proposed device will also be able to identify tumor margins in the millimeter-wave images of skin lesions. This capability will simplify the tumor removal surgery to a single-layer excision procedure. The proposed imager will be used by dermatologists and dermatologic surgeons prior to biopsy or tumor excision, facilitating the detection and removal of tumors. 

This Small Business Technology Transfer Program (STTR) Phase I project is focused on developing a fully-integrated ultra-wideband millimeter-wave imaging system for the first time. This will be realized by employing the synthetic ultra-wideband imaging approach, where several disjointed, adjacent imaging sub-bands are integrated to collectively form an ultra-wide imaging bandwidth. Each sub-band contains a transmitting and a receiving element that operate only within that specific sub-band. In this research, the RF front-ends of sub-band phased-array antennas will be developed and integrated with the transceiver components of the imaging system on a single chip. The developed phased arrays will be configured to radiate and collect RF frequencies over different frequency sub-bands, while forming independent beams with separate phase-shifting operations. Therefore, electronic beam-steering can be used for scanning the target region. In addition, a novel method for tumor margin identification in 3-D millimeter-wave images is proposed in which a-priori information about the statistical distribution of the dielectric properties of tissues is employed. This will result in a more accurate segmentation of the dielectric properties at a low computational cost. The ultra-wide bandwidth of the proposed imager will result in significantly higher image resolutions compared to the state-of-the-art millimeter-wave imaging technology.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The primary objective of this Small Business Technology Transfer project is to develop a hand-held imaging device with the capability to differentiate between different types of skin cancer, benign tissues, and normal skin as well as identify tumor margins pre- or intra-operatively. Although several non-invasive imaging tools have been developed for the diagnosis and management of skin cancer, they each have limitations on their uses and provide optimal outcomes only under certain conditions. No imaging tool has been widely adopted in the clinics. There is a definite need for an imaging tool that could visualize tumor profiles with sufficient contrasts throughout the depth of the skin at an affordable cost. The goal of this project is to deliver such a product.

The proposed imager is based on the millimeter-wave imaging technology. Electromagnetic waves at millimeter-wave frequencies possess distinctive advantages such as high image contrasts and suitable penetration depths into the tissue which make them highly desirable in a biomedical imaging context. The proposal team has developed a novel imaging technique which improved resolutions of millimeter-wave imaging systems to the levels that are sufficient for skin cancer imaging. Prior to Phase I of this research, the capability of the proposed technology in differentiating different types of skin cancer from benign tissues and normal skin had been verified. This will result in a significant decrease in the number of unnecessary biopsies, saving time and effort for dermatologists. However, the potential capability of identifying tumor margins pre- or intra-operatively needed to be verified.

During Phase I of this research, a novel deep-learning based method was developed for tumor margin identification. In order to identify tumor margins, the border between the normal and tumor parts needs to be identified. Therefore, the images need to be segmented into tumor and normal areas. The developed method is a deep learning technique which divides the millimeter-wave images into two regions (tumor and normal) with high accuracy. A recurrent auto-encoder network architecture was presented that incorporates the conventional image reconstruction modeling. To train the proposed model, a feasible mechanism was set up to provide a surrogate dataset essential for training. The effectiveness of the algorithm was demonstrated by segmenting the reconstructed images of numerical skin phantoms. This outcome will result in an accurate segmentation of the tissue profile distribution at a low computational cost.

In another effort, radiofrequency (RF) front-end components of an imaging chip were developed which allow for electronically beam-steering to scan the target region. The imaging chip possesses a novel configuration for low-loss distribution of broadband generated pulses as well as coherent spatial combining of received pulses. Specifically, a phased-array transceiver front-end with an ultra-wide imaging bandwidth of 100 GHz was realized which employs the synthetic ultra-wideband millimeter-wave imaging approach. 

The development of the skin imaging device proposed in this research will address the current clinical need for an affordable imaging methodology that images the skin over its while offering large contrasts between normal, malignant, and benign tissues. Skin cancer is the most common and fastest growing of all cancer types. The incidence rates of this cancer have soared in recent years due to the lack of proper detection and management tools. The proposed system will be an invaluable assistance to dermatologists and dermatologic surgeons and significantly enhance the current state of skin cancer detection and management. The proposed system will be integrated in a single framework, resulting in a compact (handheld) and real-time imager at a low manufacturing cost. This will make the proposed technology comparable in cost to dermatoscopic imaging, facilitating its widespread use and application. The proposed device will also be able to identify tumor margin in the millimeter-wave images of skin lesions. This capability will simplify the tumor removal surgery to a single-layer excision procedure. The proposed imager will be used by dermatologists and dermatologic surgeons prior to biopsy or tumor excision, facilitating the detection and removal of tumors. Medical imaging industry will greatly benefit from these integration procedures and the associated cost reductions.

 


Last Modified: 02/15/2023
Modified by: Amir Mirbeik-Sabzevari
